content.description: In order to study the behavior of oscillating systems, a group of students sets up the three pendulums shown in the figure. Pendulum A consists of a small sphere of mass <math alttext="M sub 0" display="inline" overflow="scroll" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><msub><mi>M</mi><mn>0</mn></msub></math> connected to a light string of length <math alttext="uppercase L sub 0" display="inline" overflow="scroll" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><msub><mi>L</mi><mn>0</mn></msub></math>. Pendulum B consists of a uniform bar of the same mass <math alttext="M sub 0" display="inline" overflow="scroll" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><msub><mi>M</mi><mn>0</mn></msub></math> and length <math alttext="uppercase L sub 0" display="inline" overflow="scroll" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><msub><mi>L</mi><mn>0</mn></msub></math> suspended from a pivot at one end. Pendulum C consists of a bar identical to the one in Pendulum B, but the pivot for Pendulum C is in the middle of one of the long edges of the bar. The width of the bars used for pendulums B and C is <math alttext="the fraction uppercase L sub 0 over 15" display="inline" overflow="scroll" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mfrac><msub><mi>L</mi><mn>0</mn></msub><mn>15</mn></mfrac></math>, and the rotational inertia about the center of a uniform bar of mass <math alttext="M" display="inline" overflow="scroll" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mi>M</mi></math> and length <math alttext="uppercase L" display="inline" overflow="scroll" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mi>L</mi></math> is <math alttext="I equals, one twelfth M uppercase L squared" display="inline" overflow="scroll" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mstyle displaystyle="true"><mi>I</mi><mo>=</mo><mfrac><mn>1</mn><mn>12</mn></mfrac><mi>M</mi><msup><mi>L</mi><mn>2</mn></msup></mstyle></math>.
content.question: The three pendulums are each displaced by a small angle from equilibrium and released. Which of the following options correctly compares the periods <math alttext="T sub A" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>T</mi><mtext>A</mtext></msub></math>, <math alttext="T sub B" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>T</mi><mtext>B</mtext></msub></math>, and <math alttext="T sub C" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>T</mi><mtext>C</mtext></msub></math> of the pendulums?

choices.label: <math alttext="T sub A is greater than T sub B, which equals T sub C" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle displaystyle="true"><msub><mi>T</mi><mtext>A</mtext></msub><mo>></mo><msub><mi>T</mi><mtext>B</mtext></msub><mo>=</mo><msub><mi>T</mi><mtext>C</mtext></msub></mstyle></math>

<math alttext="T sub A is greater than T sub B, which is greater than T sub C" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle displaystyle="true"><msub><mi>T</mi><mtext>A</mtext></msub><mo>></mo><msub><mi>T</mi><mtext>B</mtext></msub><mo>></mo><msub><mi>T</mi><mtext>C</mtext></msub></mstyle></math>

<math alttext="T sub C is greater than T sub A, which is greater than T sub B" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>T</mi><mtext>C</mtext></msub><mo>></mo><msub><mi>T</mi><mtext>A</mtext></msub><mo>></mo><msub><mi>T</mi><mtext>B</mtext></msub></math>

<math alttext="T sub C is greater than T sub B, which is greater than T sub A" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>T</mi><mtext>C</mtext></msub><mo>></mo><msub><mi>T</mi><mtext>B</mtext></msub><mo>></mo><msub><mi>T</mi><mtext>A</mtext></msub></math>

content.answer: <math alttext="T sub C is greater than T sub A, which is greater than T sub B" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>T</mi><mtext>C</mtext></msub><mo>></mo><msub><mi>T</mi><mtext>A</mtext></msub><mo>></mo><msub><mi>T</mi><mtext>B</mtext></msub></math>

skill.text: 2.C: Compare physical quantities between two or more scenarios or at different times and locations in a single scenario.
